message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ‘double bubble’ sign and narrowing of the second part of the duodenum indicate duodenal obstruction, which is most commonly seen in annular pancreas. Meckel diverticulum can cause small bowel obstruction, but not in this case. Leukocyte adhesion deficiency and Crigler-Najjar type 1 have no association with intestinal obstruction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ‘double bubble’ sign on abdominal imaging along with upper intestinal obstruction suggests duodenal obstruction. Among the options, annular pancreas can cause duodenal obstruction by encircling the duodenum. Meckel diverticulum can also cause intestinal obstruction, but it is more commonly found in the ileum. Leukocyte adhesion deficiency is a rare genetic disorder that affects the immune system and has no association with intestinal obstruction. Crigler-Najjar type 1 is a rare genetic disorder that affects bilirubin metabolism and usually presents with jaundice, not intestinal obstruction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The double bubble sign and narrowing of the second part of the duodenum suggest duodenal atresia, which can be caused by annular pancreas. Meckel diverticulum is a common congenital malformation, but it would present with lower GI symptoms. Leukocyte adhesion deficiency and Crigler-Najjar type 1 do not cause intestinal obstruction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The "double bubble" sign on abdominal imaging suggests duodenal atresia, and the narrowing of the second part of duodenum seen on computed tomography shows it is associated with annular pancreas. Meckel diverticulum is a common cause of lower gastrointestinal bleeding, while leukocyte adhesion deficiency and Crigler-Najjar type 1 do not present with intestinal obstruction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The double bubble sign and narrowing of the second part of the duodenum suggest a duodenal obstruction, which could be caused by annular pancreas. Meckel diverticulum would cause ileal obstruction, while leukocyte adhesion deficiency and Crigler-Najjar type 1 are not associated with intestinal obstruction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and imaging findings (double bubble sign with duodenal narrowing) suggest duodenal obstruction, and among the options, only annular pancreas is a known cause of duodenal obstruction. Meckel diverticulum can lead to ileal obstruction, leukocyte adhesion deficiency is a rare genetic disorder affecting immune system function and Crigler-Najjar type 1 is a rare genetic disorder affecting bilirubin metabolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ‘double bubble’ sign and narrowing of the second part of the duodenum indicate duodenal obstruction, which is a characteristic feature of annular pancreas. Meckel diverticulum may also present with intestinal obstruction, but it is rare in the first few days of life. Leukocyte adhesion deficiency and Crigler-Najjar type 1 are not associated with intestinal obstruction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ‘double bubble’ sign and the narrowing of the second part of the duodenum suggest duodenal atresia, which can be caused by annular pancreas. Meckel diverticulum is a common cause of lower intestinal obstruction. Leukocyte adhesion deficiency and Crigler-Najjar type 1 are not causes of intestinal obstruction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The “double bubble” sign on imaging and upper intestinal obstruction suggest that the most likely cause is annular pancreas, which occurs when the head of the pancreas encircles the second part of the duodenum. Meckel diverticulum could also cause intestinal obstruction but usually appears in the ileum. Leukocyte adhesion deficiency and Crigler-Najjar type 1 are not related to intestinal obstruction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The “double bubble” sign and upper intestinal obstruction suggests duodenal atresia. Among the options, only annular pancreas can cause duodenal atresia. Meckel diverticulum can cause intestinal obstruction, but it is more commonly associated with lower GI bleeding. Leukocyte adhesion deficiency and Crigler-Najjar type 1 are not associated with intestinal obstruction.
